head.title: 3 MacArthur Fellows Are Adding Value to the World of Money

EVERY year since 1981, it has been a cross between a Pulitzer and a lottery: the fellowship program of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, which awards sizable, no-strings-attached grants to a diverse group of creative thinkers.

To choose recipients, the foundation uses a confidential group of nominators and a selection committee. Earlier this month, the foundation announced 29 such fellows -- distributing grants, to be paid over five years, that ranged from $220,000 to $375,000, depending on the recipient's age.

Among the winners were three whose work involves innovative perspectives on money matters: a rancher who has taken steps to preserve his Southwestern way of life; a geographer who studies how labor and political issues help mold a cultural landscape, and an economist who aims to apply the ideals of feminism and the left to calculations of productivity.
Don Mitchell 'People's Geography Of the United States'

''Mansfield Park,'' by Jane Austen, contains a passage of special significance to Don Mitchell, 36, a cultural geographer at Syracuse University who has just won a $235,000 grant for his work on how human activity influences the natural landscape.

In the book, when Mr. Rushworth vows to improve his home at Southerton Court but wonders who will help, Miss Bertram chimes in: ''Your best friend upon such an occasion would be Mr. Repton, I imagine.''
Mr. Repton was Humphrey Repton, a famous English landscape gardener who lived at the turn of the 18th century and laid out the gardens and parks surrounding many great country houses.

''Repton is a fascinating figure who illustrates how human aesthetic sense and wealth can be part of the process of constructing the space we live in,'' Mr. Mitchell said last week in a phone conversation from Scotland where he was visiting the parents of his wife, Susan Millar, who is also a geography professor.

Mr. Mitchell's specialty is the influence of political conflict on the landscape. In ''The Lie of the Land: Migrant Workers and the Californian Landscape'' (University of Minnesota Press, 1996), he explored how the endless struggles between big farming interests and migrant workers shaped the state's agricultural landscape.
''The way the land looks today is the result of these debates and arguments,'' he said in the phone interview.

As an example, he pointed to the labor camps built for migrant workers in California's central valley after the strikes of 1933 and 1934 because authorities feared a social explosion if the farmers failed to improve conditions for their help. ''You only find decent living and washing facilities where the workers were militant,'' he said.

As other examples of the way social or political conflicts can shape a landscape, Mr. Mitchell cites Tompkins Square Park in Manhattan's East Village and the People's Park near the campus of the University of California at Berkeley.

Both parks, he said, are products of long political battles among various interests, including city and university bureaucrats, local residents, environmentalists and advocates of the rights of homeless people.
In New York, a result has been a space that now serves the needs of local residents, while in Berkeley the university constructed a park where it had originally planned to build dormitories.

Mr. Mitchell, born in Walnut Creek, Calif., came to Syracuse University in 1997 from the University of Colorado in Boulder, where he had taught since gaining a doctorate in geography from Rutgers University in 1992.
He said he had no firm idea yet how he would spend his award: ''I'm not an entrepreneur. I like teaching.''

But he would like to assemble a team of geographers and historians to write what he calls ''a people's geography of the United States,'' which would chart the development of Americans' ''social relationship with their landscape.''
PAUL LEWIS
EARNING IT
